**Guidance = how hard the model is forced to obey your conditioning (prompt + CLIP + any conditioning from LoRAs / IP-adapters / etc.) instead of just following the image prior and its own learned defaults.**

## First: the mental model (so every node choice makes sense)
A mask is just a greyscale image:

- **Black = â€œleave this aloneâ€**
- **Grey = â€œchange a bit / blend edgeâ€**

2) the edge is too hard (needs **blur/feather**), or  
3) the mask doesnâ€™t cover enough (needs **grow/dilate**).

Once you can invert / blur / grow, you can mask.

# A. The fastest way to learn masking (avoid MaskEditor entirely)
Since you already know GIMP and youâ€™ve done black/white masks before, this is the cleanest pipeline.

### 1) In GIMP (or any editor)

- Create a new layer on top.
- Paint **white** where you want changes (shirt area), **black** elsewhere.
- Export that mask as **PNG** (same dimensions as the base image).

### 2) In ComfyUI (the â€œit just worksâ€ setup)

3. **Image to Mask** (or **Mask From Image**)

5. **Blur Mask (Fast)**

**Emily:**

Youâ€™re not *doing* something â€œwrongâ€ so much as running into a real limitation of how LoRAs + masking work in most ComfyUI pipelines.

## The core problem
A **mask controls *where pixels are allowed to change*** (the â€œnoise maskâ€ / inpaint area).

A **LoRA changes the *modelâ€™s weights*** (i.e., *how the model draws everything*), and by default it applies **globally**. So even if only one face is â€œeditable,â€ the model is still *thinking* through the LoRA everywhere during the denoise steps.

Thatâ€™s why you see these two failure modes:

### 1) â€œIf I only use the LoRA trigger word, the rest degradesâ€
Because youâ€™ve removed the â€œscene anchor.â€ The model is now trying to re-solve the whole imageâ€™s meaning with almost no guidance besides â€œbe this person.â€ Even if only a region is allowed to change, the inpaint region needs **context** to match lighting/style/age/ethnicity/etc. Otherwise you get a face that doesnâ€™t belong (and edges/lighting look wrong), which reads as â€œthe whole image degraded.â€

### 2) â€œIf I use the full original prompt, all faces changeâ€
That typically means youâ€™re **not actually running a true inpaint/noise-mask workflow** (or the sampler is effectively denoising the whole latent). In many graphs, you can *have a mask present* but the sampler is still getting a latent that doesnâ€™t carry the mask, so it treats it like img2img and everything becomes eligible to drift.

---

# Step 1: Make sure youâ€™re doing *real* inpainting
Depending on your setup, **any one** of these being wrong causes â€œmask ignoredâ€ behavior:

### âœ… You must feed the sampler a latent that includes a mask
Look for one of these patterns:

- **VAE Encode (for Inpainting)** â†’ outputs a latent suitable for inpaint  
  (it takes **image + mask** and bakes mask into the latent)

or

- A node that explicitly sets a **noise_mask** on the latent (names vary by pack)

If youâ€™re using plain **VAE Encode** (not â€œfor inpaintingâ€) with a separate mask floating around, many samplers will just ignore the mask.

### âœ… Your sampler must support masked latents
Most do, but if youâ€™re using Fluxâ€™s `SamplerCustomAdvanced`, the mask has to be present in the latent in the way Flux expects. The safest approach is: **use the inpaint-specific encode path**.

### âœ… Quick sanity test
Mask a tiny square on a wall/background and prompt â€œput a small framed picture here.â€
- If anything outside the square changes: youâ€™re not in true inpaint.

---

# Step 2: Stop trying to â€œprompt lessâ€ â€” prompt *anchored + local*
For single-face edits in a crowd, use **two layers of text guidance**:

## A) Keep the *original* prompt, but add an anchor line
Add one short line that tells the model to preserve everything except the mask:

> â€œkeep everyone else the same, do not change other faces, preserve composition, preserve lighting, preserve clothingâ€

It sounds silly, but it helps the model â€œaimâ€ inside the allowed area.

## B) Localize the identity influence
If your LoRA is strong, it will â€œwantâ€ to infect the whole image *conceptually*.

So:
- keep LoRA strength a bit lower than you would for a full portrait
- rely on the **mask + denoise** to do the work

Typical starting points:
- **LoRA model strength:** 0.5â€“0.8 (depends on LoRA quality)
- **Denoise:** 0.35â€“0.55 for face-only swaps (higher if it refuses to change)
- **(FluxGuidance):** stay in your stable zone (e.g., 2.8â€“3.6) unless youâ€™re forcing a stubborn identity

# Step 3: The â€œthis always worksâ€ method for crowd shots: Crop â†’ inpaint â†’ stitch
This is the method I recommend when you only want **one** face to change and nothing else.

1) **Detect / crop** the target face (Impact Pack SEGS/BBox nodes are perfect for this)
2) Run an **inpaint** on the cropped patch (mask only the face)
3) **Stitch/composite** it back into the original image

(If you tell me whether you have Impact Pack available â€” it sounds like you do â€” Iâ€™ll give you a minimal node chain using the exact node names you likely have.)

# Step 4: If you really want â€œLoRA only inside mask,â€ you need regional LoRA routing
Masking alone canâ€™t truly apply LoRA *only* to one region, because LoRA is global weights.

To truly localize:

- **Regional conditioning tools** (e.g., ConditioningSetArea / Regional Prompterâ€“style nodes)

### What that error usually means
`'Linear' object has no attribute 'weight_scale'`

That message is almost always a **mismatch between what a hook/patch node expects a layer to look like** and what the model loader actually gave it.

Those Hook LoRA / CLIP Hook nodes typically â€œreach insideâ€ the text encoder and touch layer attributes that only exist when the encoder is wrapped in a **specific quant/patch wrapper** (FP8/INT8-ish wrappers often carry extra tensors like *weight_scale*, *scales*, etc).

If the node expects â€œFP8-wrapped Linear (with weight_scale)â€ but it encounters a plain `torch.nn.Linear`, it dies exactly like this.

So the failure isnâ€™t â€œCLIP Text Encode is brokenâ€ â€” itâ€™s â€œsomething upstream changed what CLIPâ€™s Linear layers are.â€

### Why it can seem random (your â€œblows my hypothesis out of the waterâ€ moment)
You can get *the same workflow* to sometimes work and sometimes fail because one of these changed between runs:

1. **Which exact SRPO checkpoint variant you loaded**  
   Many people have multiple SRPO files (fp16 vs fp8_e4m3fn etc). One may load with wrappers that include `weight_scale`, another may not.

2. **Which text encoder path got used**  
   Some workflows silently swap between different text encoders / loaders depending on availability (or cached objects). If you â€œreplaced the modelâ€ but the graph still used a cached CLIP object from a previous run, the run can succeed onceâ€¦ then fail after a restart.

3. **ComfyUI update changed the wrapping behavior**  
   If ComfyUI (or a related backend) changed how it instantiates FP8 layers, the hook node may now see a plain Linear where it previously saw a wrapped Linear.

4. **The Hook nodes updated (or didnâ€™t), while ComfyUI did**  
   This is the classic: ComfyUI internals change â†’ custom node that monkey-patches layers now expects attributes that no longer exist.

### The fastest way to confirm whatâ€™s happening
Do this in your ComfyUI folder:

**A) Find who is referencing `weight_scale`**
```bash

```
That will point to the exact custom node file thatâ€™s exploding.

**B) Then check what it *assumes***
Youâ€™ll likely see something like:
- `module.weight_scale`  
- or a loop that assumes every Linear has that attribute

If you see it, youâ€™ve basically proven the diagnosis: **the hook node is coded for a wrapped Linear class, but your current SRPO/CLIP stack is giving it a plain one.**

### Practical fixes (in the order Iâ€™d try them)
#### 1) Update the Hook nodes repo (not just ComfyUI)
If you installed via Manager, still go to the node folder and do a pull:

If you switch from `SRPO-fp8_e4m3fn` to an fp16 SRPO and the error vanishes, thatâ€™s very strong evidence that:
- the hook node expects FP8 wrapper attributes in one place, **or**
- FP8 wrapping changed and removed/renamed `weight_scale`.

#### 3) Try swapping the text encoder node (even if the diffusion model stays SRPO)
If your workflow has multiple text-encode options (Flux-specific encoders, â€œstandardâ€ CLIP encoders, etc), test the other one.  
The hook node might only support one path.

#### 4) If you want a â€œmake it work todayâ€ workaround: donâ€™t hook CLIP â€” regional-condition instead
If your goal is *two consistent people left/right*, you can avoid CLIP-hooks entirely by doing:

- Branch A: Load model+clip â†’ apply LoRA A â†’ encode prompt A  
- Branch B: Load model+clip â†’ apply LoRA B â†’ encode prompt B  
- Set area/region for each conditioning (left half vs right half)

## 1) Why your â€œitâ€™s silently using old stuffâ€ theory is plausible
ComfyUI **does cache** model objects in-process (checkpoints, CLIP/T5, VAE). On top of that, a lot of custom nodes (and especially hook/patch systems) **mutate** those objects in-place.

So you can absolutely get situations where:

- you â€œchange a modelâ€ in a loader node, but
- the loader hands you a cached object for that filename/dtype combo, *or*
- you are still using a previously patched encoder object because the graph reuses the same CLIP/T5 object reference, *or*
- a hook node patched something globally and it persists until restart

Thatâ€™s why â€œit worked today even though it shouldnâ€™tâ€ can happen.

**Rule of thumb:** any time youâ€™re debugging a hook/quantization issue, treat each test as â€œclean-roomâ€: **restart ComfyUI between runs**.

## 2) The `kolors/chatglm/quantization.py` â€œweight_scaleâ€ hits are a huge clue
